The Latin translation, as regards classic style and fidelity to the original, pos- sesses only ordinary merit. Here and there, words and phrases are added. In some instances, the language is a paraphrase instead of a translation; in others it fails to give the true sense of the original German. It cannot, accordingly, be assigned a place beside the original text. It has no normal authority. Yet it possesses great value for the purposes of reference and comparison.

The Modern German text is edited on the basis of the original Catechism as pub- lished by N iemeyer, no clause or word being allowed to stand unless warranted by this criterion of judgment. It differs from the old text only in so far as the German language of to-day itself differs from the German language in use three hundred years ago, The difference pertains to orthography, the inflection of nouns and verbs, the gender of nouns, and to certain words and idioms which are now nearly or altogether obsolete. In the execution of this part of the work, the Committee acknowledges the valuable cooperation of the Rev. Prof. Philip Schaff, D. D.
